pageProps.body:
Nonhomogeneous Equations

We begin with an important result that will be used throughout our discussion in this section:

Theorem. "Nonhomogeneous" shall be used instead of "inhomogeneous" (with certain exceptions, e.g. when I forget to).

Proof. I think "nonhomogeneous" sounds cooler. □\square□

Now that that's out of the way, we move on to less important things.

Definition. Nonhomogeneous second-order DEs are ones of the form

L[y](t)=g(t)L[y](t) = g(t)L[y](t)=g(t)

where L[y](t)L[y](t)L[y](t) is as defined above, and g(t)g(t)g(t) is any function of ttt that is nonzero. The equation

L[y](t)=0L[y](t) = 0L[y](t)=0

is thus referred to as the homogeneous equation corresponding to L[y](t)=g(t)L[y](t) = g(t)L[y](t)=g(t), and was discussed at length in the previous section.

To proceed, we formulate several statements that may seem trivial, but are important to our upcoming discussion:

Theorem. Solutions to inhomogeneous equations. (Solutions to inhomogeneous equations). If Y1Y_1Y1​ and Y2Y_2Y2​ are both solutions to a certain inhomogeneous DE L[y](t)=g(t)L[y](t) = g(t)L[y](t)=g(t), then Y1−Y2Y_1-Y_2Y1​−Y2​ is a solution to the corresponding homogeneous equation.

This can be easily proven by substituting Y1Y_1Y1​ and Y2Y_2Y2​ into the DE; thus, we have Y1−Y2=c1y1+c2y2Y_1 - Y_2 = c_1 y_1 + c_2 y_2Y1​−Y2​=c1​y1​+c2​y2​ for fundamental solutions y1y_1y1​ and y2y_2y2​ and constants c1,c2c_1, c_2c1​,c2​. As such, it quickly follows that

Theorem. Solutions to inhomogeneous equations. The general solution to L[y](t)=g(t)L[y](t) = g(t)L[y](t)=g(t) can be fully described by

y(t)=c1y1+c2y2+Y(t)y(t) = c_1y_1 + c_2 y_2 + Y(t)y(t)=c1​y1​+c2​y2​+Y(t)

where c1y1+c2y2c_1 y_1 + c_2 y_2c1​y1​+c2​y2​ is the general solution to the homogeneous equation and Y(t)Y(t)Y(t) is a specific solution to the inhomogeneous equation.

Proof. As proven by the above theorem, for any two solutions Y1Y_1Y1​ and Y2Y_2Y2​ to L[y](t)=g(t)L[y](t) = g(t)L[y](t)=g(t), we have Y1−Y2=c1y1+c2y2Y_1 - Y_2 = c_1y_1 + c_2y_2Y1​−Y2​=c1​y1​+c2​y2​. Thus set Y1=y(t)Y_1 = y(t)Y1​=y(t) and Y2=Y(t)Y_2 = Y(t)Y2​=Y(t) to obtain the desired result.

The implications of the above results inform us on how to approach such inhomogeneous equations:

  1. First, we should approach the corresponding homogeneous equation and obtain its solutions.
  2. We should then find some specific solution Y(t)Y(t)Y(t) to the inhomogeneous equation.
  3. The general solution will be the combination of the results of the above two steps.

The second step of finding a specific solution, in particular, is of interest to us in this section. To this end, we present two different approaches:

Method. (Method of undetermined coefficients).

..."Method of undetermined coefficients" is a more civilized way to say guessing. The method is guessing.

The idea behind this method is that the right-hand side g(t)g(t)g(t) of the inhomogeneous equation can enable us to make educated guesses about what the solution might look like; for example, if it's an exponential function, then it's a bit unlikely that the solution will be a polynomial. We will assume the solution to be in some form (e.g. eaxe^{ax}eax where aaa is unknown), set the coefficients of that form to be unknown, and then plug it into the DE to find the coefficients.

A table of what solution to guess based on the form of g(t)g(t)g(t) is shown below:

g(t)g(t)g(t)Solution to guess
Exponential (eate^{at}eat)beatbe^{at}beat
\sin kt, \cos kt$Asin⁡kt+Bcos⁡ktA \sin kt + B \cos ktAsinkt+Bcoskt
Pn(t)P_n(t)Pn​(t) (Polynomial of deg nnn)Polynomial of the same degree
Pn(t)eatP_n(t)e^{at}Pn​(t)eatQn(t)eatQ_n(t)e^{at}Qn​(t)eat
Pn(t)sin⁡kt,Pn(t)cos⁡ktP_n(t)\sin kt, P_n(t)\cos ktPn​(t)sinkt,Pn​(t)cosktQn(t)sin⁡kt+Rn(t)cos⁡ktQ_n(t)\sin kt + R_n(t)\cos ktQn​(t)sinkt+Rn​(t)coskt

...where Pn(t),Qn(t),Rn(t)P_n(t), Q_n(t), R_n(t)Pn​(t),Qn​(t),Rn​(t) represent polynomials of degree nnn for some nnn. Essentially, whenever we have an elementary function multiplied by a polynomial for g(t)g(t)g(t), guess a polynomial of the same degree for the solution. The proof of the above cases is left to the reader. (Yes, I'm making you do my dirty work.)

One thing to note about this method: the degenerate sub-case. (And no, that is not a description of myself.) What happens if the solution we guess turns out to be part of the homogeneous equation's solution? For instance, what if we guess Ae4xAe^{4x}Ae4x, but e4xe^{4x}e4x is a fundamental solution to the corresponding homogeneous equation? In this case - like in the repeated root case for constant coefficients before it - we multiply our original guessed solution with ttt, then proceed as normal. If the solution is still degenerate, then t2t^2t2 will do.

The main limitation of this method is its scope: it does not apply to anything other than linear or multiplicative combinations of elementary functions (trig, exponential, algebraic) - for instance, sin⁡et\sin e^tsinet sould lead to absolute collapse. So what happens if the right-hand side of the inhomogeneous equation is more complicated?

Method. (Method of variation of parameters). This method presents a general method for solving inhomogeneous second-order DEs, applicable to any equation; in fact, it is powerful enough to derive a general formula for the solution of any such equation. However, it involves considerably greater work and effort than the undetermined coefficients method, and the latter is still preferable when the right-hand side is a fairly simple function.

We begin by returning to our general inhomogeneous DE:

y′′+p(t)y′+q(t)=g(t)y'' + p(t)y' + q(t) = g(t)y′′+p(t)y′+q(t)=g(t)

and its corresponding homogeneous DE:

y′′+p(t)y′+q(t)=0y'' + p(t)y' + q(t) = 0y′′+p(t)y′+q(t)=0

At this point, let us assume that the solutions to the homogeneous DE (the complementary function) are already known to be encompassed by the fundamental solutions y1y_1y1​ and y2y_2y2​:

y(t)=c1y1+c2y2y(t) = c_1 y_1 + c_2 y_2y(t)=c1​y1​+c2​y2​

Recall how, in previous sections (repeated roots case in constant coefficients), we managed to obtain one fundamental solution (y2=Ateλty_2 = Ate^{\lambda t}y2​=Ateλt) off the other fundamental solution (y1=eλty_1 = e^{\lambda t}y1​=eλt) by setting y2=v(t)y1y_2 = v(t) y_1y2​=v(t)y1​, leading to a differential equation in vvv.

We will try something similar here. Let the specific solution to the inhomogeneous DE - i.e. the particular integral - be yp(t)y_p(t)yp​(t), and assume that it is in the form

yp=v1y1+v2y2y_p = v_1 y_1 + v_2 y_2yp​=v1​y1​+v2​y2​

where v1v_1v1​ and v2v_2v2​ are both functions of ttt. If we try to plug this in to the DE immediately, we obtain a sealed eldritch monstrosity from the ninth circle of hell that should have never been unleashed onto our plane of existence because repeated applications of the product rule leads to more than ten terms.

More importantly, if we just plug this into the DE with nothing else, we have two variables/functions that need to be solved for (v1v_1v1​ and v2v_2v2​) and only one equation. This would yield an infinite number of solutions; we only need one solution for yp(t)y_p(t)yp​(t), so let us impose another equation on v1v_1v1​ and v2v_2v2​.

But what is this other equation we should impose? Let's try finding yp′y_p'yp′​ to get more information, as we want yp′y_p'yp′​ to be as simple as possible:

yp′=v1′y1+v1y1′+v2′y2+v2y2′y_p' = v_1'y_1 + v_1y_1' + v_2'y_2 + v_2y_2'yp′​=v1′​y1​+v1​y1′​+v2′​y2​+v2​y2′​

Our top priority is to make sure that v1v_1v1​ and v2v_2v2​ do not have second-order derivatives, because they are the variables we want to solve for and a second-order DE is much harder than a first-order one to solve. Thus, we don't want any v1′v_1'v1′​ or v2′v_2'v2′​ terms in yp′y_p'yp′​. For this reason, we propose that our other equation is as follows:

v1′y1+v2′y2=0v_1'y_1 + v_2'y_2 = 0v1′​y1​+v2′​y2​=0

so that no v1′v_1'v1′​ or v2′v_2'v2′​ terms appear in yp′y_p'yp′​ and thus no second-order derivatives appear in yp′′y_p''yp′′​. We continue along this vein:

yp′=v1′y1+v1y1′+v2′y2+v2y2′=v1y1′+v2y2′y_p' = v_1'y_1 + v_1y_1' + v_2'y_2 + v_2y_2' = v_1y_1' + v_2y_2'yp′​=v1′​y1​+v1​y1′​+v2′​y2​+v2​y2′​=v1​y1′​+v2​y2′​

from our other equation, and thus

yp′′=v1′y1′+v1y1′′+v2′y2′+v2y2′′y_p'' = v_1'y_1' + v_1y_1'' + v_2'y_2' + v_2y_2''yp′′​=v1′​y1′​+v1​y1′′​+v2′​y2′​+v2​y2′′​

This gives us enough information to plug in back to the original DE:

yp′′+p(t)yp′+q(t)yp=g(t)v1′y1′+v1y1′′+v2′y2′+v2y2′′+p(t)(v1y1′+v2y2′)+q(t)(v1y1+v2y2)=g(t)v1(y1′′+p(t)y1′+q(t)y1)+v2(y2′′+p(t)y2′+q(t)y2)+v1′y1′+v2′y2′=g(t)\begin{aligned} y_p'' + p(t)y_p' + q(t)y_p &= g(t) \\ v_1'y_1' + v_1y_1'' + v_2'y_2' + v_2y_2'' + p(t)(v_1y_1' + v_2y_2') + q(t)(v_1y_1 + v_2y_2) &= g(t) \\ v_1(y_1'' + p(t)y_1' + q(t)y_1) + v_2(y_2''+p(t)y_2' + q(t)y_2) + v_1'y_1' + v_2'y_2' &= g(t) \end{aligned}yp′′​+p(t)yp′​+q(t)yp​v1′​y1′​+v1​y1′′​+v2′​y2′​+v2​y2′′​+p(t)(v1​y1′​+v2​y2′​)+q(t)(v1​y1​+v2​y2​)v1​(y1′′​+p(t)y1′​+q(t)y1​)+v2​(y2′′​+p(t)y2′​+q(t)y2​)+v1′​y1′​+v2′​y2′​​=g(t)=g(t)=g(t)​

where everything in the parentheses in the final equation is zero due to y1y_1y1​ and y2y_2y2​ being solutions to the homogeneous equation. As such, we finally obtain

v1′y1′+v2′y2′=g(t)v_1'y_1' + v_2'y_2' = g(t)v1′​y1′​+v2′​y2′​=g(t)

as well as our other equation

v1′y1+v2′y2=0v_1'y_1 + v_2'y_2 = 0v1′​y1​+v2′​y2​=0

which gives us a system of equations in v1′v_1'v1′​ and v2′v_2'v2′​:

{v1′y1′+v2′y2′=g(t)v1′y1+v2′y2=0\begin{cases} v_1'y_1' + v_2'y_2' = g(t) \\ v_1'y_1 + v_2'y_2 = 0 \end{cases}{v1′​y1′​+v2′​y2′​=g(t)v1′​y1​+v2′​y2​=0​

This gives us enough information to find the general solution.

Theorem. (General solution for inhomogeneous second-order differential equations). The particular integral yp(t)y_p(t)yp​(t) for any inhomogeneous second-order DE, with its corresponding homogeneous equation having fundamental solutions y1y_1y1​ and y2y_2y2​, is given by:

{yp(t)=v1y1+v2y2v1=−∫g(t)y2W(y1,y2)(t) dtv2=∫g(t)y1W(y1,y2)(t)\begin{cases} y_p(t) = v_1y_1 + v_2y_2 \\ v_1 = -\int \frac{g(t)y_2}{W(y_1,y_2)(t)} \ dt \\ v_2 = \int \frac{g(t)y_1}{W(y_1,y_2)(t)} \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​yp​(t)=v1​y1​+v2​y2​v1​=−∫W(y1​,y2​)(t)g(t)y2​​ dtv2​=∫W(y1​,y2​)(t)g(t)y1​​​

Proof.

Proceed from the system of equations above: multiplying the second equation by y1′y1\frac{y_1'}{y_1}y1​y1′​​ obtains

v1′y1′+v2′y1′y2y1=0v_1'y_1' + v_2'\frac{y_1'y_2}{y_1} = 0v1′​y1′​+v2′​y1​y1′​y2​​=0

and subtracting from the first obtains

v2′(y1y2′−y1′y2y1)=g(t)v_2'(\frac{y_1y_2' - y_1'y_2}{y_1}) = g(t)v2′​(y1​y1​y2′​−y1′​y2​​)=g(t)

which very conveniently contains a Wronskian:

W(y1,y2)=y1y2′−y1′y2W(y_1,y_2) = y_1y_2' - y_1'y_2W(y1​,y2​)=y1​y2′​−y1′​y2​

and hence

v2′=g(t)y1W(y1,y2)(t)v_2' = \frac{g(t)y_1}{W(y_1,y_2)(t)}v2′​=W(y1​,y2​)(t)g(t)y1​​

Substituting into the second equation gives

v1′y1=−v2′y2v1′=−g(t)y1W(y1,y2)(t)y2y1=−g(t)y2W(y1,y2)(t).\begin{aligned} v_1'y_1 &= -v_2'y_2 \\ v_1' &= -\frac{g(t)y_1}{W(y_1,y_2)(t)}\frac{y_2}{y_1} \\ &= -\frac{g(t)y_2}{W(y_1,y_2)(t)}. \end{aligned}v1′​y1​v1′​​=−v2′​y2​=−W(y1​,y2​)(t)g(t)y1​​y1​y2​​=−W(y1​,y2​)(t)g(t)y2​​.​

which is our desired result.
